title: Labour MP quits to join House of Lords
text:
Former Labour MP John Mann during a protest against antisemitism within party (Picture: PA Archive)

The Government’s antisemitism tsar has left the green seats of the House of Commons after 18 years to sit in the Lords’ red pews.

John Mann was elected as Labour MP for Bassetlaw, Nottinghamshire, in 2001 but will be a non-affiliated member in the upper house after standing down.

Lord Mann was appointed in July by former prime minister Theresa May to lead a government inquiry on tackling antisemitism.

The politician, now Lord Mann of Holbeck Moor, chaired the cross-party parliamentary group and has been a critic of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn’s handling of the issue.

His departure will trigger a by-election in his former Nottinghamshire constituency unless the speculated general election is called.

Lord Mann received his life peerage in Theresa May’s resignation honours list (Picture: PA Wire)

Lord Mann had previously announced his decision to stand down and not run at the next election. It is not clear whether delays to Brexit and doubt over when any election would take place expedited his decision.

Lord Mann told the Yorkshire Press however that the current political turmoil had ‘paralysed’ parliament.

He added: ‘The power of the Prime Minister, Speaker and the whips will all need to be reconsidered if our democracy is to properly function. I am not holding my breath at such maturity.’

Voters in the Bassetlaw sided nearly two to one in favour of leaving the European Union in the 2016 referendum. If a bye-election is called it would provide a considerable litmus test for Boris Johnson’s government and Brexit strategy.

Lord Mann, who has previously called for the House of Lords to be abolished, was nominated in Theresa May’s resignation honour’s list.

He was one of 19 Labour MPs who voted for Boris Johnson’s Brexit bill at second reading in parliament last week.

Lord Mann’s office has been contacted for comment.
